metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: If you do not want to use any of the standard fonts in HTML, you can use Google Fonts.
content.html: If you do not want to use any of the standard fonts in HTML, you can use Google Fonts.

content.text: Google Fonts are free to use, and have more than 1000 fonts to choose from.
content.html: Google Fonts are free to use, and have more than 1000 fonts to choose from.

content.text: Just add a special style sheet link in the <head> section and then refer to the font in the CSS.
content.html: Just add a special style sheet link in the <head> section and then refer to the font in the CSS.

content.code_html:
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Sofia">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;
}
</style>
</head>

<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Trirong">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Trirong", serif;
}
</style>
</head>

<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Audiowide">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Audiowide", sans-serif;
}
</style>
</head>

content.text: Note: When specifying a font in CSS, always list at minimum one fallback font (to avoid unexpected behaviors). So, also here you should add a generic font family (like serif or sans-serif) to the end of the list.
content.html: Note: When specifying a font in CSS, always list at minimum one fallback font (to avoid unexpected behaviors). So, also here you should add a generic font family (like serif or sans-serif) to the end of the list.

content.text: For a list of all available Google Fonts, visit our How To - Google Fonts Tutorial .
content.html: For a list of all available Google Fonts, visit our How To - Google Fonts Tutorial.

content.text: To use multiple Google fonts, just separate the font names with a pipe character ( | ), like this:
content.html: To use multiple Google fonts, just separate the font names with a pipe character (|), like this:

content.code_html:
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Audiowide|Sofia|Trirong">
<style>
h1.a {font-family: "Audiowide", sans-serif;}
h1.b {font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;}
h1.c {font-family: "Trirong", serif;}
</style>
</head>

content.text: Note: Requesting multiple fonts may slow down your web pages! So be careful about that.
content.html: Note: Requesting multiple fonts may slow down your web pages! So be careful about that.

content.text: Of course you can style Google Fonts as you like, with CSS!
content.html: Of course you can style Google Fonts as you like, with CSS!

content.code_html:
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Sofia">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;
  font-size: 30px;
  text-shadow: 3px 3px 3px #ababab;
}
</style>
</head>

content.text: Google has also enabled different font effects that you can use.
content.html: Google has also enabled different font effects that you can use.

content.text: First add effect= effectname to the Google API, then add a special class name to the element that is going to use the special effect. The class name always starts with font-effect- and ends with the effectname .
content.html: First add effect=effectname to the Google API, then add a special class name to the element that is going to use the special effect. The class name always starts with font-effect- and ends with the effectname.

content.code: Sofia on Fire
content.code_html:
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Sofia&effect=fire">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;
  font-size: 30px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h1 class="font-effect-fire">Sofia on Fire</h1>

</body>

content.text: To request multiple font effects, just separate the effect names with a pipe character ( | ), like this:
content.html: To request multiple font effects, just separate the effect names with a pipe character (|), like this:

content.code:
Neon Effect

Outline Effect

Emboss Effect

Multiple Shadow Effect
content.code_html:
<head>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Sofia&effect=neon|outline|emboss|shadow-multiple">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;
  font-size: 30px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h1 class="font-effect-neon">Neon Effect</h1>
<h1 class="font-effect-outline">Outline Effect</h1>
<h1 class="font-effect-emboss">Emboss Effect</h1>
<h1 class="font-effect-shadow-multiple">Multiple Shadow Effect</h1>

</body>
